articles.headline: Eyeing the Trump Voter, ‘Fight for $15’ Widens Its Focus
articles.snippet: Beyond the urban working poor, the effort is aiming at those frustrated by an economy no longer producing middle-class jobs they or their parents once held.
articles.abstract: Beyond the urban working poor, the effort is aiming at those frustrated by an economy no longer producing middle-class jobs they or their parents once held.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the labor-financed “Fight for $15” campaign say they have improved the lives of millions of workers at the bottom of the nation’s pay scale, helping to raise the minimum wage in California, New York State and a host of cities.

articles.headline: China Tightens Controls on Overseas Use of Its Currency
articles.snippet: With money surging out of China, the Chinese central bank makes it harder for Chinese customers of banks to complete overseas transfers.
articles.abstract: With money surging out of China, the Chinese central bank makes it harder for Chinese customers of banks to complete overseas transfers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As an exodus of money adds to the pressure on a slowing economy, regulators are trying to put the brakes on overseas use of China’s currency by increasing the scrutiny of certain overseas deals.

articles.headline: Trump Taps Hollywood’s Mnuchin for Treasury and Dines With Romney
articles.snippet: Steven Mnuchin, a longtime Trump acquaintance, is a former Goldman Sachs partner who has worked in hedge funds and Hollywood finance and has no government experience.
articles.abstract: Steven Mnuchin, a longtime Trump acquaintance, is a former Goldman Sachs partner who has worked in hedge funds and Hollywood finance and has no government experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Steven Mnuchin, a financier with deep roots on Wall Street and in Hollywood but no government experience, is expected to be named Donald J. Trump’s Treasury secretary as soon as Wednesday, people close to the transition say.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Binyamin Appelbaum and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Despite Climate Change Vow, China Pushes to Dig More Coal
articles.snippet: China is reopening mines amid worries about power supplies, demonstrating how difficult it will be to wean its giant economy from coal dependence.
articles.abstract: China is reopening mines amid worries about power supplies, demonstrating how difficult it will be to wean its giant economy from coal dependence.
articles.lead_paragraph: JINCHENG, China — America’s uncertain stance toward global warming under the coming administration of Donald J. Trump has given China a leading role in the fight against climate change. It has called on the United States to recognize established science and to work with other countries to reduce dependence on dirty fuels like coal and oil.

articles.headline: Trump to Announce Carrier Plant Will Keep Jobs in U.S.
articles.snippet: Reversing a plan the president-elect had assailed, the company will keep roughly half of the 2,000 manufacturing jobs in Indiana that it was to shift to Mexico.
articles.abstract: Reversing a plan the president-elect had assailed, the company will keep roughly half of the 2,000 manufacturing jobs in Indiana that it was to shift to Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the earliest days of his campaign, Donald J. Trump made keeping manufacturing jobs in the United States his signature economic issue, and the decision by Carrier, the big air-conditioner company, to move over 2,000 of them from Indiana to Mexico was a tailor-made talking point for him on the stump.

articles.headline: Tom Price, H.H.S. Nominee, Drafted Remake of Health Law
articles.snippet: Mr. Price’s bill, the Empowering Patients First Act, would weaken many consumer protections in the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s signature domestic achievement.
articles.abstract: Mr. Price’s bill, the Empowering Patients First Act, would weaken many consumer protections in the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s signature domestic achievement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In choosing Representative Tom Price of Georgia to be his health secretary, President-elect Donald J. Trump has signaled an undiminished determination to repeal President Obama’s signature domestic achievement, the Affordable Care Act, and replace it with a health law that would be far less comprehensive.

articles.headline: Steven Mnuchin, Expected Treasury Pick, Is an Outsider to Public Policy
articles.snippet: He never ran a large organization or showed himself to be an accomplished economist. But he is very much a part of the firmament of the finance world.
articles.abstract: He never ran a large organization or showed himself to be an accomplished economist. But he is very much a part of the firmament of the finance world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Mnuchin started his career as a trader.

articles.headline: French Election Hints at a European Shift Toward Russia
articles.snippet: François Fillon’s victory in a presidential primary suggests that a shift from confrontation to accommodation of Moscow has already begun in the region.
articles.abstract: François Fillon’s victory in a presidential primary suggests that a shift from confrontation to accommodation of Moscow has already begun in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: The victory of François Fillon in France’s center-right presidential primary is the latest sign that a tectonic shift is coming to the European order: toward accommodating, rather than countering, a resurgent Russia.

articles.headline: Another Mass Grave Dug by ISIS in Iraq, and a Ghastly Ritual Renewed
articles.snippet: The Islamic State has been resorting to a horrific practice that dates back to Saddam Hussein and his regime’s industrial-scale killings.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State has been resorting to a horrific practice that dates back to Saddam Hussein and his regime’s industrial-scale killings.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMAM AL-ALIL, Iraq — The battle was over in Hamam al-Alil, Iraq, an old spa resort town that the country’s security forces had wrested from the Islamic State a few days ago, but one Iraqi soldier was still on a very personal mission.

articles.headline: While We Weren’t Looking, Snapchat Revolutionized Social Networks
articles.snippet: Once known for its disappearing messages, Snap, the parent of Snapchat, has moved into news and, with Spectacles, consumer devices.
articles.abstract: Once known for its disappearing messages, Snap, the parent of Snapchat, has moved into news and, with Spectacles, consumer devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Snap Inc., the parent company of the popular photo-messaging and storytelling app Snapchat, is having a productive autumn.

articles.headline: OPEC Reaches Deal to Limit Production, Sending Prices Soaring
articles.snippet: The deal will be the first production cut in eight years, although the price increase may prove temporary.
articles.abstract: The deal will be the first production cut in eight years, although the price increase may prove temporary.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — After years of trying fruitlessly to prop up energy markets, OPEC on Wednesday finally reached a consensus on production cuts, sending oil prices soaring. The problem is, the euphoria in the markets may not last.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Ethics Office Praises Donald Trump for a Move He Hasn’t Committed To
articles.snippet: In a series of oddly informal Twitter posts, the Office of Government Ethics appeared to conclude, wrongly, that Mr. Trump had promised to divest his assets.
articles.abstract: In a series of oddly informal Twitter posts, the Office of Government Ethics appeared to conclude, wrongly, that Mr. Trump had promised to divest his assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Office of Government Ethics has informed lawyers for President-elect Donald J. Trump that only a divestiture of his financial stake in his sprawling real estate business will resolve ethical concerns about conflicts of interest as he assumes the office of the presidency.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Eric Lipton
